data.title: On this day, 43 years ago, Josip Broz Tito died
data.meta_description: 43 years ago, on May 4, 1980, the president for life of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (SFRJ) Josip Broz Tito, the leader of the Yugoslav partisans in World War II and the leader of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia, died. Get the most important news, free on Viber The journalist who told Yugoslavia that Tito died: I felt that he was in sight... On this day 43 years ago, Josip Broz Tito died Read More »
data.text:
43 years ago, on May 4, 1980, the president for life of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (SFRJ) Josip Broz Tito, the leader of the Yugoslav partisans in World War II and the leader of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia, died.

The journalist who told Yugoslavia that Tito was dead: I felt the biggest crisis was in sight

As Beta reported, he took the country out of the Soviet bloc, initiated its comprehensive development and was one of the leaders of the Non-Aligned Movement.

He was the head of Yugoslavia from 1945 until his death, and he died at the age of 88, at the Clinical Center in Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia, at 15:5 p.m.

For several years, on May 4 at 15.05:XNUMX p.m., the sirens sounded and the transport stopped, and the citizens of Jugolsavia stood still and paid their respects to Tito in silence.

The forty-third anniversary of Tito's death will be celebrated today in the House of Flowers in Belgrade, where he was buried, in Kumrovec, Croatia, where he was born, and in several other places.

Tito's grave, the House of Flowers, which is part of the Museum of Yugoslavia in Dedinje, has been visited by about 20 million people since the funeral.

His funeral was attended by more than 200 delegations from around the world, presidents, prime ministers, kings and rulers and party leaders from 107 countries.

Josip Broz Tito was born in Kumrovec in May 1892. His birthday was celebrated on May 25, as "Youth Day".

Tito: How did the nickname of the lifelong president of Yugoslavia come about?
